column11: Review Text
Lots of shacks where one can rent sunbeds for 300 Sri Lankan Rs to spend the entire day and also rent out a surf board to get surf lessons. The water was clean and the beach had stunning white sand.
It was a clear, sunny day and we had the best time by the beach. A cute shack where we got sunbeds for 300 Sri Lankan Rs to spend the entire day and also rent out a surf board to catch those waves.
Lovely and clean, with soft sand. Only some small hotels, no noisy eateries. Can get surfboards during season but rough during off season.
Highly recommend this beach for learning to surf. There's also a number of good restaurants that are family and budget traveller friendly. Try Cafe Ceylon and Mellow Hostel.

This was our favourite beach in Southern Sri Lanka. Quiet and safe with lovely local bars and cafe. Say Hi to Noty at his bar on the beach, friendly service and right on the beach.. This was our favourite place to hang out at the end of a day
We have been all over the world on lots of beaches and this was by far the best we have seen in a long time. The sand was fine and beautiful. The beach was clean and not over crowded.
The beach is a very nice, white sand with warm water. Good for beginning surfers. Restaurants and bars on the beach with lounge chairs. Great for a beach walk.

Stunning beaches, great waves. An all round favorite beach holiday. However, The sea pollution after a storm was diabolical (I’m talking loads and loads of plastic, rope, flip flops and even medical waste like needles thrown up by the rough seas)... While tourists (us included) took it upon ourselves to clean the beaches.... the locals, whose livelihoods depend on the beaches being clean, didn’t seem too perturbed and didn’t join in the clean up efforts. It’s our second vacation to this beautiful beach and the cleanliness of the beaches and ocean have noticibly declined. On the upside, many restaurants and cafes are serving paper or reusable straws which is a great sign. I do love coming to Sri Lanka and this beach in particular, I just feel that some ownership should be taken by tourists and locals alike to maintain the beaches.
We love to stay at kabalana beach. Good for learn surfing. The wave not so strong. We love the small place over there. They have coconut and beds. We stay there all day and night.
Great place to swim and learn how to surf! Lots of great restaurants along the beach and many lounge chairs to relax with on
Sugar sand, Beautiful long beach, I love it. A lot of foreigners are there & i heard Kabalana s the main surf beach in the ares.

This beach is usually good for beginner surfers, but we struck a few days of difficult waves (Dec). Lots of places to rent boards and loungers, make sure you enquire about price before hand and a bit of gentle bargaining is Ok, but generally prices seem to be fixed unless you arrange something for a week. It is a nice beach but I still recommend going to other places for a look and experience. Service in the restaurants is pretty slow, but we weren't in a hurry.

We were there for a spend the day, and the staff helped us to get a pleasant experience at the hotel. Need some improvements with the food! It’s just on the beach and we had a good time. You can enjoy the kabalanaa beach from this hotel, and easy access to main cities. Like the construction concept with old egyption paints and statues. Thank you for the good service! Hope to visit again!
This stretch of beach is not polluted and still remains quite clean by beach standards. Its a long stretch too. I'm told there are safer stretches to take a dip too but this needs to be verified.
A shallow beach with good waves for the surfers. Sometimes a bit annoying streetdogs. Perfect for families also.
Wonderfull beach heat surf and no hassle. Surf boards for rent and surf lessons available loved it! I would recommend it to anyone interested in a great beach
Kabalana Beach is fantastic the ocean is clear and more importantly, warm enough even for my wife to go in everyday without the usual screaming!!!!!!!!

So this is how the scam works: They get you to sign a piece of paper to rent the surfboard (which doesn't happen anywhere else in Sri Lanka that I've found). They then pretend to check the fins are in good condition, but they don't really, they lightly touch them so as to not let on that one is already broken. Then as you're walking out into the water the broken fin comes off so you go back and they blame you and charge you several thousand rupees more than a fin is worth. Oh, and they follow you home with a group of their mates if you don't have the money on you. The fin that they pre-broke was worth less than 2000lkr and they tried to charge us 6000lkr. The people at our accommodation told us that these guys on the beach are always scamming people and getting into fights so beware.

This is a nice sandy beach, which has much less people than the busy beach in Mirissa. I would recommend going here if you want a bit more solitude rather than the beach party scene. You can take a tuk tuk from Mirissa, it would probably take about 20 minutes, but you have to be very careful about hailing tuk tuks on the road. If you can, use a trusted one from your hotel rather than one from the road.
